Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Very-Near-Ground Wireless Channel Modeling: Theory and Practice

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop channel models for radio wave propagation with antennas installed very near ground (H+), at ground level (H0), and/or covered by ice, water, snow, or other materials (H-). The approach is to evaluate the temporal, spatial and spectral statistical characteristics of very near ground antenna channels through simulations, analysis, and measurements conducted in an anechoic chamber and in real environments.

Intellectual Merit: The conducted research includes: 1) development of physics-based propagation models for H+/H0/H- radio channels over a wide range of frequencies to address a variety of applications; 2) exploration of the effect of transmitter and receiver antenna heights, frequency, bandwidth, rough surface materials, and the degree of roughness on the channel model; 3) investigation of near-ground channel dispersion and its impact on direction-of-arrival and time-of-arrival estimation; 4) study of the effect of ground roughness and bandwidth on amplitude, phase, and time-of-arrival statistics in both line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight scenarios as well as spatial correlation and its effect on multi-input-multi-output systems; and 5) design of proper antenna elements and antenna arrays for H+/H0/H- situations.

Broader Impacts: This research should enable optimal design of wireless sensor networks and localization systems for applications such as autonomous collision avoidance, multi-robot collaboration, safety services (firefighting), and under-ground exploration, which would benefit the national economy and security. This project integrates research with education and outreach activities. The theoretical work is demonstrated by practical applications through laboratory activities and measurement processes. Hands-on experiences will be provided for undergraduate students and school teachers. Underrepresented minority students will be recruited into engineering education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal aims at addressing a fundamental problem in the growing area of wireless sensor networks (WSN) . In the emerging applications of WSN and localization such as unmanned vehicles and autonomous collision avoidance, antennas are installed very near the ground, at the ground level, and/or covered by ice, water, snow, or other materials. Measurements and practical experiences have confirmed that current wireless systems do not perform well in situations where both ends of a wireless link are very close to the ground. Development of proper near ground channel models are vital for high performance communication as the design parameters of wireless systems are selected based on channel models created via theoretical modeling and empirical measurements. To operate in very-near-ground environments, future wireless systems must be designed and optimized to address the associated issues and challenges. Very-near-ground channels are affected by ground roughness, ground material, vegetation, and temporal variations caused by environmental effects (rain, snow, temperature, vegetation growth, etc.). In addition, the performance of these channels is highly influenced by antenna features such as polarization, structure, shape, and size. 

The project conducted in depth theoretical and applied research on channel modeling and localization for near ground scenarios. Path loss models and their impact on receiver performance, network capacity and localization for near ground scenarios with applications in Boarder Control, Environmental Monitoring, Vehicular Technology, underground and underwater systems were investigated. In addition to the theoretical research detailed in the uploaded report, we conducted a comprehensive near ground measurement campaign with the support of REU students and through integration of research with Education as part of Wireless Communication and Digital Communication course projects. Graduate students who took the courses along with REU students were able to attain considerable hands on experience on measurement devices, and also statistical analysis of data to extract desired channel information such as Path Loss and Coherence Distance. Diverse students including African American and Women (including REU program) engaged in the project.
